page.title: 11 Housing in Barham
page.content: The original village,comprising the oldest houses,is centred around the village green.Some of these are over three hundred years old.Two modern estates have been built at one end of the village. One consists mainly of private semi-detached bungalows,the other is a council estate.There are a few infillings of modern houses within the main village,eg.three new houses by the pub"The Duke of Cumberland."From our survey the most common dwelling place is the detached house,the majority having been built after 1900.Most dwellings have brick walls with tiled roofs.The older houses tend to use local materials such as flint or brick and white weatherboarding for the walls,whilst roofing tiles are of the Kent peg variety.
